messages.content:
You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

Output:
{
  "citations": [
    {
      "ref_index": 38,
      "titles": [
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "Towards federated learning at scale: System design",
        "A performance evaluation of federated learning algorithms",
        "Distributed machine learning: A survey",
        "Communication protocols for distributed learning",
        "Scalable federated learning systems",
        "Efficient distributed training algorithms",
        "Large-scale distributed learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]38 appears in the context of 'massively distributed networks' for federated learning, so it likely refers to foundational papers on federated learning systems, distributed training, and communication-efficient methods in distributed networks."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 5,
      "titles": [
        "Bagging predictors",
        "Ensemble methods in machine learning",
        "Random forests for classification",
        "Bootstrap methods and their application",
        "Combining multiple classifiers",
        "Large-scale machine learning systems",
        "Distributed ensemble methods",
        "Scalable classification algorithms",
        "Massive data processing techniques",
        "High-performance machine learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]5 appears in the context of 'at a large scale', suggesting it refers to papers on scaling machine learning methods, ensemble techniques, or methods that can handle large-scale data and distributed settings."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 30,
      "titles": [
        "Learning fair representations",
        "Fair machine learning: A survey",
        "Bias in machine learning systems",
        "Addressing fairness in AI systems",
        "Fair representation learning",
        "Heterogeneous data handling methods",
        "Multi-source learning algorithms",
        "Cross-domain representation learning",
        "Fair learning from diverse data",
        "Bias mitigation in heterogeneous datasets"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]30 appears in the context of 'heterogeneous data' and 'fair representation learning', indicating it likely refers to papers on heterogenous data handling, bias mitigation, and learning representations that are fair across different data distributions."
    }
  ]
}

CRITICAL: Return ONLY the JSON object. Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not use markdown formatting. Ensure all quotes and special characters are properly escaped.

IMPORTANT NOTES ON REASONING:
- The reasoning field is crucial for preventing hallucination
- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: Static Analysis of Logic Programs via Boolean Networks

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
We start with revisiting one well-known result in ASP (see PropositionÂ 4).
We provide a new proof for it, which relies on the relation between an LP and a BN. Let Pğ‘ƒP be an LP.
If dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has no cycle, then Pğ‘ƒP has exactly one stable model. Let fğ‘“f be the encoded BN of Pğ‘ƒP.
Since dg+â€‹(P)âŠ†dgâ€‹(P)superscriptdgğ‘ƒdgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}^{+}({P})\subseteq\text{dg}({P}), dg+â€‹(P)superscriptdgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}^{+}({P}) has no cycle, then smâ€‹(P)=suppâ€‹(P)smğ‘ƒsuppğ‘ƒ\text{sm}({P})=\text{supp}({P}) by TheoremÂ 1.
Since igâ€‹(f)âŠ†dgâ€‹(P)igğ‘“dgğ‘ƒ\text{ig}({f})\subseteq\text{dg}({P}), igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}) has no cycle.
By Theorem 1 ofÂ [ref]33, fğ‘“f has a unique fixed point, thus Pğ‘ƒP has a unique stable model.
âˆ PropositionÂ 4 is the consequence of Theorem 2.5(iv) ofÂ  and Fagesâ€™ theorem.
Theorem 2.5(iv) ofÂ  shows that if dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has no cycle, then cfâ€‹(P)cfğ‘ƒ\text{cf}({P}) has a unique model, which is also the unique stable model of Pğ‘ƒP by Fagesâ€™ theorem.
Indeed, the BN-based proof that we provide here is quite simpler than the above proof.
We then present two newly small results considering LPs with very special structures (see PropositionsÂ 5 andÂ 6).
See ExampleÂ 2 for illustration. Let Pğ‘ƒP be an LP.
Suppose that dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) is a positive cycle.
If dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has a negative arc, then Pğ‘ƒP has exactly two stable models.
Otherwise, Pğ‘ƒP has exactly one stable model. Let fğ‘“f be the BN encoding of Pğ‘ƒP.
Since dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) is a positive cycle, the in-degree of each vertex is one, leading to every fvsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘£f_{v} is constant-free.
Hence, igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}) is also a positive cycle.
ByÂ , fğ‘“f has exactly two fixed points.
If dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has a negative arc, then dg+â€‹(P)superscriptdgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}^{+}({P}) has no cycle.
It follows that suppâ€‹(P)=smâ€‹(P)suppğ‘ƒsmğ‘ƒ\text{supp}({P})=\text{sm}({P}) by TheoremÂ 1.
Hence, Pğ‘ƒP has exactly two stable models.
If dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has no negative arc, then Pğ‘ƒP is positive.
Hence, it has exactly one stable model.

Otherwise, the unique stable model of Pğ‘ƒP is âˆ…\emptyset. Let Pğ‘ƒP be an LP.
Suppose that dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) is a negative cycle.
Then Pğ‘ƒP has no stable model. Let fğ‘“f be the BN encoding of Pğ‘ƒP.
Since dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) is a negative cycle, the in-degree of each vertex is one, leading to every fvsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘£f_{v} is constant-free.
Hence, igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}) is also a negative cycle.
ByÂ , fğ‘“f has no fixed point.
It follows that Pğ‘ƒP has no supported model.
Since a stable model is also a supported model, Pğ‘ƒP has no stable model.
âˆ Let P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} be the LP: aâ†âˆ¼b;bâ†âˆ¼c;câ†aa\leftarrow{\sim}{b};b\leftarrow{\sim}{c};c\leftarrow a.
Let P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} be the LP: aâ†b;bâ†âˆ¼c;câ†aa\leftarrow b;b\leftarrow{\sim}{c};c\leftarrow a.
FiguresÂ 2(a) andÂ 2(b) show the DGs of P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2}, respectively.
dgâ€‹(P1)dgsubscriptğ‘ƒ1\text{dg}({P_{1}}) is a positive cycle and it has two negative arcs.
P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} has two stable models (A1={a,c},A2={b}formulae-sequencesubscriptğ´1ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ´2ğ‘A_{1}=\{a,c\},A_{2}=\{b\}), which is consistent with PropositionÂ 5.
We also see that A1âˆ©A2=âˆ…subscriptğ´1subscriptğ´2A_{1}\cap A_{2}=\emptyset and A1âˆªA2={a,b,c}=atomâ€‹(P1)subscriptğ´1subscriptğ´2ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘atomsubscriptğ‘ƒ1A_{1}\cup A_{2}=\{a,b,c\}=\text{atom}({P_{1}}).
dgâ€‹(P2)dgsubscriptğ‘ƒ2\text{dg}({P_{2}}) is a negative cycle and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} has no stable model, which is consistent with PropositionÂ 6. Next, we investigate more deeply the effect of positive and negative cycles of the DG of Pğ‘ƒP on its stable models.
Recall that a Positive Feedback Vertex Set (PFVS) of a signed directed graph GğºG is a set of vertices intersecting all positive cycles of GğºGÂ [ref]33. Let Pğ‘ƒP be an LP.
If Pğ‘ƒP has two distinct stable models (say A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} and A2subscriptğ´2A_{2}), then dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has a positive cycle C+superscriptğ¶C^{+} such that for every vâˆˆC+ğ‘£superscriptğ¶v\in C^{+}, either vâˆˆA1ğ‘£subscriptğ´1v\in A_{1} or vâˆˆA2ğ‘£subscriptğ´2v\in A_{2}. Let fğ‘“f be the BN encoding of Pğ‘ƒP.
A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} and A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} are also distinct supported models of Pğ‘ƒP.
By TheoremÂ 3, A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} and A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} are distinct fixed points of fğ‘“f.
By Lemma 1111If fğ‘“f has two fixed points xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y, then igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}) has a positive cycle C+superscriptğ¶C^{+} such that xvâ‰ yv,âˆ€vâˆˆC+formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘£for-allğ‘£superscriptğ¶x_{v}\neq y_{v},\forall v\in C^{+}. ofÂ [ref]33, igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}) has a positive cycle C+superscriptğ¶C^{+} such that for every vâˆˆC+ğ‘£superscriptğ¶v\in C^{+}, A1â€‹(v)â‰ A2â€‹(v)subscriptğ´1ğ‘£subscriptğ´2ğ‘£A_{1}(v)\neq A_{2}(v), i.e., either vâˆˆA1ğ‘£subscriptğ´1v\in A_{1} or vâˆˆA2ğ‘£subscriptğ´2v\in A_{2} because A1â€‹(v),A2â€‹(v)âˆˆğ”¹subscriptğ´1ğ‘£subscriptğ´2ğ‘£ğ”¹A_{1}(v),A_{2}(v)\in\mathbb{B}.
C+superscriptğ¶C^{+} is also a positive cycle of dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) because igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}) is a subgraph of dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}).
âˆ If a sign directed graph GğºG is strongly connected and has no negative cycle or has no positive cycle, then GğºG is sign-definite. We first prove that each arc of GğºG belongs to a cycle in GğºG (*).
Taken an arbitrary arc (uâ€‹v,Ïµ)ğ‘¢ğ‘£italic-Ïµ(uv,\epsilon) in GğºG.
Since GğºG is strongly connected, there is a directed path from vğ‘£v to uğ‘¢u.
By adding (uâ€‹v,Ïµ)ğ‘¢ğ‘£italic-Ïµ(uv,\epsilon) to this path, we obtain a cycle. Assume that GğºG is not sign-definite.
Then there are two arcs: (uâ€‹v,âŠ•)ğ‘¢ğ‘£direct-sum(uv,\oplus) and (uâ€‹v,âŠ–)ğ‘¢ğ‘£symmetric-difference(uv,\ominus).
By (*), (uâ€‹v,âŠ•)ğ‘¢ğ‘£direct-sum(uv,\oplus) (resp. (uâ€‹v,âŠ–)ğ‘¢ğ‘£symmetric-difference(uv,\ominus)) belongs to a cycle in GğºG (say Cğ¶C).
Cğ¶C is a positive (resp. negative) cycle because GğºG has no negative (resp. positive) cycle.
Then (Câˆ’(uâ€‹v,âŠ•))+(uâ€‹v,âŠ–)ğ¶ğ‘¢ğ‘£direct-sumğ‘¢ğ‘£symmetric-difference(C-(uv,\oplus))+(uv,\ominus) (resp. (Câˆ’(uâ€‹v,âŠ–))+(uâ€‹v,âŠ•)ğ¶ğ‘¢ğ‘£symmetric-differenceğ‘¢ğ‘£direct-sum(C-(uv,\ominus))+(uv,\oplus)) is a negative (resp. positive) cycle in GğºG.
This implies a contradiction.
Hence, GğºG is sign-definite.
âˆ Let Pğ‘ƒP be an LP.
If dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has no positive cycle, then Pğ‘ƒP has at most one stable model.
In addition, if Pğ‘ƒP has no fact and every atom appears in the head of a rule in Pğ‘ƒP, then Pğ‘ƒP has no stable model. Assume that Pğ‘ƒP has at least two stable models.
Then dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has a positive cycle by LemmaÂ 7, which is a contradiction.
Hence, Pğ‘ƒP has at most one stable model. Since Pğ‘ƒP no fact and every atom appears in the head of a rule in Pğ‘ƒP, each vertex of dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has at least one input vertex.
Let Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} be a strongly connected subgraph of dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) such that there is no arc from a vertex outside Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} to a vertex in Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*}.
Since dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has no positive cycle, then Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} also has no positive cycle.
By LemmaÂ 8, Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} is sign-definite.
Let fğ‘“f be the BN encoding of Pğ‘ƒP.
Since there is no arc from a vertex outside Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} to a vertex in Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*}, there is a BN fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*} on the set of variables that are vertices of Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} and fvâˆ—=fv,âˆ€vâˆˆvarfâˆ—formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘£subscriptğ‘“ğ‘£for-allğ‘£subscriptvarsuperscriptğ‘“f^{*}_{v}=f_{v},\forall v\in\text{var}_{{f^{*}}}. Since each vertex of dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has at least one input vertex, each vertex of Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} also has at least one input vertex.
Let vğ‘£v be an arbitrary vertex in Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*}.
Since Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} is sign-definite, the sets of positive and negative input vertices of vğ‘£v are disjoint.
By assigning 0 to all positive input vertices of vğ‘£v in Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} and 1 to all negative input vertices of vğ‘£v in Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*}, we have fvâˆ—=0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘£0f^{*}_{v}=0.
Symmetrically, assigning 1 to all positive input vertices of vğ‘£v in Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*} and 0 to all negative input vertices of vğ‘£v in Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*}, we have fvâˆ—=1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘£1f^{*}_{v}=1.
Hence, fvâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘£f^{*}_{v} cannot be constant.
It implies that the minimum in-degree of iâ€‹gâ€‹(fâˆ—)ğ‘–ğ‘”superscriptğ‘“ig(f^{*}) is at least one.
Clearly, iâ€‹gâ€‹(fâˆ—)ğ‘–ğ‘”superscriptğ‘“ig(f^{*}) is a subgraph of Gâˆ—superscriptğºG^{*}, leading to iâ€‹gâ€‹(fâˆ—)ğ‘–ğ‘”superscriptğ‘“ig(f^{*}) has no positive cycle.
Then fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*} has no fixed point by Theorem 2222If igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}) has no positive cycle and its minimum in-degree is at least one, then fğ‘“f has no fixed point. ofÂ .
Let Î³â€‹(f)ğ›¾ğ‘“\gamma(f) and Î³â€‹(fâˆ—)ğ›¾superscriptğ‘“\gamma(f^{*}) be the SAT formulas characterizing fixed points of fğ‘“f and fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}, respectively.

Clearly, Î³â€‹(fâˆ—)ğ›¾superscriptğ‘“\gamma(f^{*}) is part of Î³â€‹(f)ğ›¾ğ‘“\gamma(f), thus Î³â€‹(f)ğ›¾ğ‘“\gamma(f) has no model.
Hence, fğ‘“f has no fixed point.
It follows that Pğ‘ƒP has no supported model.
Since a stable model is also a supported model, Pğ‘ƒP has no stable model.
âˆ Let Pğ‘ƒP be an LP.
For any PFVS U+superscriptğ‘ˆU^{+} of dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}), we have that |smâ€‹(P)|â‰¤2|U+|smğ‘ƒsuperscript2superscriptğ‘ˆ|\text{sm}({P})|\leq 2^{|U^{+}|}. Let fğ‘“f be the BN encoding of Pğ‘ƒP.
Since U+superscriptğ‘ˆU^{+} is a PFVS of dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}), dgâ€‹(P)âˆ’U+dgğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ˆ\text{dg}({P})-U^{+} has no positive cycle.
Since igâ€‹(f)âŠ†dgâ€‹(P)igğ‘“dgğ‘ƒ\text{ig}({f})\subseteq\text{dg}({P}), igâ€‹(f)âˆ’U+igğ‘“superscriptğ‘ˆ\text{ig}({f})-U^{+} also has no positive cycle.
Therefore, U+superscriptğ‘ˆU^{+} is a PFVS of igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}).
By Theorem 9 ofÂ [ref]4, |fixâ€‹(f)|â‰¤2|U+|fixğ‘“superscript2superscriptğ‘ˆ|\text{fix}({f})|\leq 2^{|U^{+}|}.
Since |smâ€‹(P)|â‰¤|fixâ€‹(f)|smğ‘ƒfixğ‘“|\text{sm}({P})|\leq|\text{fix}({f})|, we can conclude that |smâ€‹(P)|â‰¤2|U+|smğ‘ƒsuperscript2superscriptğ‘ˆ|\text{sm}({P})|\leq 2^{|U^{+}|}.
âˆ Note that PropositionÂ 10 can be directly proved by using TheoremÂ 9.
The main idea is that in any stable model of Pğ‘ƒP, each atom in U+superscriptğ‘ˆU^{+} can be either true or false.
For each assignment of atoms in U+superscriptğ‘ˆU^{+}, we get a new LP whose DG has no positive cycle, then it has at most one stable model by TheoremÂ 9.
There are 2|U+|superscript2superscriptğ‘ˆ2^{|U^{+}|} possible assignments of atoms in U+superscriptğ‘ˆU^{+}, hence we can deduce |smâ€‹(P)|â‰¤2|U+|smğ‘ƒsuperscript2superscriptğ‘ˆ|\text{sm}({P})|\leq 2^{|U^{+}|}. It is well-known in the BN field that if igâ€‹(f)igğ‘“\text{ig}({f}) has no negative cycle, then fğ‘“f has at least one fixed point (Theorem 6 ofÂ [ref]4).
Naturally, it is interesting to question whether an LP whose DG has no negative cycle has at least one stable model or not.
Fages showed a counterexample for the case of infinite logic programsÂ 4, but the case of finite logic programs is still open.
We answer this question by TheoremÂ 12. To prove TheoremÂ 12, we use the fixpoint semantics of logic programsÂ .
To be self-contained, we briefly recall the definition of the least fixpoint of a logic program.
A quasi-interpretation is a set possibly infinite of rules of the form pâ†âˆ¼p1,â€¦,âˆ¼pkp\leftarrow{\sim}{p_{1}},\dots,{\sim}{p_{k}} where kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0 and p,p1,â€¦,pkâˆˆatomâ€‹(P)ğ‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜atomğ‘ƒp,p_{1},\dots,p_{k}\in\text{atom}({P}).
Let rğ‘Ÿr be the rule pâ†âˆ¼p1,â€¦,âˆ¼pk,q1,â€¦,qjp\leftarrow{\sim}{p_{1}},\dots,{\sim}{p_{k}},q_{1},\dots,q_{j} and let risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} be rules qiâ†âˆ¼qi1,â€¦,âˆ¼qiliq_{i}\leftarrow{\sim}{q^{1}_{i}},\dots,{\sim}{q^{l_{i}}_{i}} where 1â‰¤iâ‰¤j1ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i\leq j and liâ‰¥0subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–0l_{i}\geq 0.
Then Trâ€‹({r1,â€¦,rj})subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘—T_{r}(\{r_{1},\dots,r_{j}\}) is the rule pâ†âˆ¼p1,â€¦,âˆ¼pk,âˆ¼q11,â€¦,âˆ¼q1l1,â€¦,âˆ¼qj1,â€¦,âˆ¼qjlj.p\leftarrow{\sim}{p_{1}},\dots,{\sim}{p_{k}},{\sim}{q_{1}^{1}},\dots,{\sim}{q_{1}^{l_{1}}},\dots,{\sim}{q_{j}^{1}},\dots,{\sim}{q_{j}^{l_{j}}}. We now introduce the transformation TPsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ƒT_{P} on quasi-interpretations: TPâ€‹(Q)={Trâ€‹({r1,â€¦,rj})|râˆˆP,riâˆˆQ,1â‰¤iâ‰¤j}.subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘„conditional-setsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘—formulae-sequenceğ‘Ÿğ‘ƒformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘„1ğ‘–ğ‘—T_{P}(Q)=\{T_{r}(\{r_{1},\dots,r_{j}\})|r\in P,r_{i}\in Q,1\leq i\leq j\}. Let lfpi=TPiâ€‹(âˆ…)=TPâ€‹(TPâ€‹(â€¦â€‹TPâ€‹(âˆ…)))subscriptlfpğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ƒâ€¦subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ƒ\text{lfp}_{i}=T_{P}^{i}(\emptyset)=T_{P}(T_{P}(\dots T_{P}(\emptyset))), then lfp=â‹ƒiâ‰¥1lfpilfpsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptlfpğ‘–\text{lfp}=\bigcup_{i\geq 1}\text{lfp}_{i} is the least fixpoint of Pğ‘ƒP. Let Pğ‘ƒP be an LP and Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime} be its least fixpoint.
If dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has no negative cycle, then dgâ€‹(Pâ€²)dgsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\text{dg}({P^{\prime}}) has no negative cycle. By Lemma 5.3 ofÂ 4, if vertex ağ‘a has a negative path to vertex bğ‘b in dgâ€‹(Pâ€²)dgsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\text{dg}({P^{\prime}}), then ağ‘a has also a negative path to bğ‘b in dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}).
Note that the set of vertices of dgâ€‹(Pâ€²)dgsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\text{dg}({P^{\prime}}) is a subset of that of dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}).
It follows that if there is a negative cycle in dgâ€‹(Pâ€²)dgsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\text{dg}({P^{\prime}}), then there is also a negative cycle in dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}).
Hence, if dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has no negative cycle, then dgâ€‹(Pâ€²)dgsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\text{dg}({P^{\prime}}) has no negative cycle.
âˆ Let Pğ‘ƒP be an LP.
If dgâ€‹(P)dgğ‘ƒ\text{dg}({P}) has no negative cycle, then Pğ‘ƒP has at least one stable model. Let Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime} be the least fixpoint of Pğ‘ƒP.
